meta.content: Our Plan for Responding to COVID-19

meta.title: Our Plan for Responding to COVID-19

body.span: Strategies for Keeping Our Community Healthy

td.style: background:#e6f5f6 none no-repeat center/cover;mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;background-color: #e6f5f6;background-image: none;background-repeat: no-repeat;background-position: center;background-size: cover;border-top: 0;border-bottom: 2px dotted #adb2b6;padding-top: 9px;padding-bottom: 9px;

h1.style: display: block;margin: 0;padding: 0;color: #333d47;font-family: Georgia, Times, 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: 36px;font-style: normal;font-weight: normal;line-height: 150%;letter-spacing: normal;text-align: left;

td.p: On Thursday, three cases of coronavirus disease 2019, or COVID-19, were confirmed in Montgomery County, Maryland. Over the last couple of weeks, we have been creating a detailed, comprehensive plan for preventing the spread of illnesses at school and responding to any instances of coronavirus within our community, should they occur.

p.a: Learn more about COVID-19 at the DC Health website.

td.p: Our plan defines protocols for addressing a COVID-19 case in a student, a staff member, a visitor to Creative Minds, or someone in a student’s or staff member’s household. It includes strategies for responding to cases in our school building and on the larger AFRH campus and for keeping community members safe on trips outside school.

The first line of defense is prevention, and we’re continuing with our usual practices for community health: encouraging and teaching students proper techniques for hand washing, thoroughly cleaning our building every day (with an extra emphasis on doorknobs and other hot spots for germs), and sending home staff and students who are sick. Anyone sent home with an illness must be fever free for 24 hours before returning to school. See our guidelines for keeping sick children home.

We’re monitoring cases of COVID-19 through DC Health and with the AFRH. Because all visitors must sign in at the front desk, we have records of who has entered the school building. Nurse Owens, as always, keeps track of who among our students and staff develops an illness.

To help us stay informed and respond quickly, please email Heather Hesslink, director of operations and compliance, if your household experiences a confirmed case of the coronavirus. We will not share the names of affected staff, students, or their family members, or provide other identifying information, to the CMI community.
We’ve developed strategies for responding to a single case of coronavirus, to multiple cases, and to an instance of the illness spreading quickly throughout our community.
As we monitor the spread of COVID-19, we’re following guidance from OSSE, DC Health, and the DC PCSB.

We’re also coordinating with the Armed Forces Retirement Home on responding to any instances of coronavirus on the campus at large. And Nurse Owens, who is our school nurse through the School Services program of Children’s National Hospital, is keeping us informed with updates from her chain of command.
We’d like to share the three plausible scenarios outlined in our response plan and our strategies for addressing them:

ul.li: Scenario 1: A confirmed case of COVID-19 within one of the eight wards of Washington, DC (not in Maryland or in Virginia)
Scenario 2: A confirmed case of COVID-19 on the AFRH campus but not among our staff, students, or visitors, and not in the household of a CMI community member
Scenario 3: A member of the CMI community—a student, staff member, or visitor, or a person who resides with a student or staff member—tests positive for COVID-19

td.p: Here are details for each scenario:

Scenario 1: Upon the first confirmed case of COVID-19 in Washington, DC, we will disinfect our school building with hospital-grade cleaners. This cleaning will happen in the evening on the day a case is reported. In addition, all field trips will be postponed or canceled until the threat has subsided.

Scenario 2: We have been working with the Armed Forces Retirement Home on a plan to maintain a safe campus for everyone who lives, learns, and works here. If there is a confirmed case of COVID-19 in the AFRH community, but not in the Creative Minds community, we will disinfect our school building with hospital-grade cleaners. This cleaning will happen either in the evening, on the day a case is reported, or as soon as we can schedule it. School will be closed until the building has been disinfected. If there are multiple cases discovered at the AFRH but not within the CMI community, we will assess the situation, in coordination with the AFRH, and send you regular updates.

Scenario 3: If a case of COVID-19 is confirmed in the CMI community, we will disinfect the school building with hospital-grade cleaners. To prevent community transfer, school will be closed for 14 calendar days, unless the DC Public Charter School Board, OSSE, DC Health, or the mayor’s office advises otherwise. During such a closure, we will send you regular updates by phone and email. We’re finishing a plan for offering students learn-at-home options, and we’re coordinating with local organizations to support families that rely on school meals.
Our cleaning company has provided details on how it would disinfect the school, and I’ve approved its protocols.

If a case of COVID-19 is confirmed within the CMI community or if we put any aspect of our plan into action—for example, if we close school for disinfection—we’ll contact you by phone and email. You can expect regular updates from us if school is closed.

The health of the Creative Minds community is our number-one priority. We’re confident about our response plan and are diligently monitoring the spread of COVID-19 and working with our partners to keep everyone at CMI safe. If you have any questions about our plan, please don’t hesitate to email Heather Hesslink.
